title: 110_hr2538
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Defend the American Dream Act of 2007". Wage determination is addressed in the Act. The "Defend the American Dream Act of 2007" addresses wage determination for H-1B nonimmigrant workers, requiring employers to offer wages at the prevailing wage level, median average wage, or median wage for skill level two in the occupational classification area. The "Defend the American Dream Act of 2007" requires employers hiring H-1B nonimmigrant workers to offer wages at the prevailing wage level, median average wage, or median wage for skill level two in the occupational classification area. Employers must also provide working conditions that do not negatively impact similarly employed workers. Additionally, employers must submit the wage determination methodology used with the application. The Secretary shall specify one or more H-1B nonimmigrants, and the application must be accompanied by the employer's IRS Form W-2 for such nonimmigrants. The amendments apply to applications filed after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. GOOD FAITH RECRUITMENT REQUIREMENT. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to extend the time period for no displacement from 90 days to 180 days, require active recruitment, and prohibit outplacement of aliens by the employer. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to extend the time period for no displacement from 90 days to 180 days, require active recruitment, and prohibit outplacement of aliens by the employer. The amendments made by this section apply to applications filed on or after the date of the enactment of this Act, except for displacements occurring more than 90 days before such date. SEC. 4. H-1B employer requirements include extending the time period for no displacement from 90 days to 180 days, requiring active recruitment, and prohibiting outplacement of aliens by the employer. The amendment to Section 212(n)(1)(C) of the Act requires job availability to be advertised for at least 30 days on a list maintained by the Department of Labor. The Secretary of Labor must establish this list within 90 days of the enactment of the paragraph. The Secretary of Labor will establish a list of available jobs that will be accessible on a website and at 1-stop centers. Each job on the list must include the employer's name and address. The required information for each job listing includes the employer's business address, city, state, zip code, Federal Employer Identification Number, contact phone number and email, wage rate (with bottom of range if applicable), pay frequency, expected hours per week, and start date. The job listing requirements include the expected start and end dates, number of employees needed, job title, description, location, and application process. The Secretary of Labor may charge a filing fee for job listings. Rules may be established after a comment period. The Secretary may establish rules for job listings, including additional information requirements. Effective 30 days after list creation, employers must advertise jobs available to all, not just H-1B nonimmigrants. The text discusses requirements for job listings to be available to all, not just H-1B nonimmigrants, and limits the percentage of H-1B employees an employer can have if they employ at least 50 people in the US. The text discusses the requirement for employers to share all immigration paperwork with employees upon request within 10 working days. SEC. 5. Removal of exemption from H-1B numerical limitation for certain aliens. Amends section 214(g)(5) of the Immigration and Nationality Act to remove certain exemptions. Effective date applies to visas issued under section 101(a)(15)(H)(i)(B) on or after the first day of the first fiscal year after enactment.

SEC. 6. Requirement of a degree from certain institutions for H-1B specialty occupation nonimmigrants. SEC. 7. LABOR ENFORCEMENT. Amends section 214(i)(2) of the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding educational institution requirements for H-1B visas. Effective for applications filed after enactment of this Act. The Secretary will handle investigations of wage complaints and fraud in H-1B visa applications. Compliance audits may be conducted for employers with H-1B nonimmigrants, especially those with a significant percentage of such employees. The Secretary will conduct annual compliance audits for employers with H-1B nonimmigrants and increase penalties for violations. SEC. 8 amends whistleblower protections under the Immigration and Nationality Act, holding employers liable for violating employee rights. SEC. 9 extends nondisplacement requirements to all H-1B employers. SEC. 9 amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to extend nondisplacement requirements to all H-1B employers, effective for applications filed after the enactment of this Act.
